name: Pressure Cooker Mashed Potatoes
description: After years of adjusting, learning from failures, and sorting through advice from others that turned out to be good or bad, I finally have a great recipe that people flip over. The two biggest tips I've learned in making these is to heat the milk and butter before mashing in, and to use a hand masher as opposed to an electric mixer. Using these methods, I have NEVER had the potatoes come out pasty or soupy, always super-fluffy with just enough body.
recipeIngredient: 3 cups cold water, or as needed
3 ½ pounds russet potatoes, peeled and sliced 3/4 inch thick

recipeInstructions.text: Bring water to a boil in a pressure cooker over high heat. When water is boiling, add potatoes. Seal lid and bring cooker up to high pressure. Reduce heat to low, maintaining high pressure, and cook for 30 minutes.

Use quick-release method to lower the pressure. Drain potatoes and return them to pressure cooker. Add butter and milk and cover pressure cooker with lid for 5 minutes, allowing the heat from the potatoes to melt the butter and warm the milk.
Remove lid. Season with kosher salt and white pepper, and use a hand masher to mash potatoes until lumps are mostly gone. Transfer to a bowl and serve hot.

review.reviewBody: Makes perfect mashed potatoes. I have a cuisinart electric pressure cooker and it only takes 5 minutes on high pressure to get the potatoes soft. I used half the salt, a little more cream, and no pepper. Excellent recipe!
These are very good potatoes although the secret is in the mashing and not the cooking. I am concerned that the potatoes could easily be over cooked as you can't check them in the pressure cooker.

Works like a charm. I used purple potatoes. They were quite small so I cooked them whole (all about the same size) peeled then mashed. It is indeed technique and method more than ingredients. The warm butter and milk are important. I made half the recipe amount so with my pressure cooker I only needed only 5 minutes from the time I closed it (water already boiling). I think times vary between cookers. Thanks for the recipe and tips!

I was a bit rushed when I made these in my Instant Pot. I brought the water to a simmer, rather than a full boil, before adding potatoes and cooked at high pressure for 4 minutes. I had to do a 10 minute natural release instead of a quick release because some of the water started to come out when I tried the quick release. I just waited about 10 minutes and then released the rest of the pressure. Nice fluffy potatoes! Thanks for a great recipe! :)

I am not sure if my pressure cooker is different but 30 minutes would cook 3/4" sliced potatoes into oblivion in my cooker... 15 minutes would be more than long enough... I normally quarter my potatoes and they cook through in less than 10 minutes. I'm at high altitude which may make a small difference!
I made this tonight with red skinned potatoes and they were AWESOME! I didn't add the milk just the butter and only used 2lb sliced but they were great. Only took 5 minutes and done!

This recipe is great but I can't imagine what 30 minutes of cooking time would do. That is crazy! I just made this ith a stove top pressure cooker. I set the timer for 5 minutes when the steam was flowing steadily. I did the rapid release to reduce pressure. I think I cooked it for at least one minute too long (if not more). After draining the potatoes I had to stir back into the hot pot to get the liquid (from overcooking) to evaporate before I could finish the recipe. Maybe 30 is a typo! I bet 3 minutes is right.

A good basic recipe, flavor-wise, but the cook time is WAY off. I used an electric pressure cooker (which cooks slightly slower than the stove-top pressure cooker used in this recipe) and assuming you use potatoes cut to the stated 3/4"size, it takes 8-10 minutes, MAX.  They wouldn't even take 30 mins if you were to boil them in a pot on the stove!  I did add a bit more milk, personal preference, and I also like the recipe creator's suggestion to add horseradish. Mashing them by hand (as in the recipe) is far superior to using a mixer to avoid gluey potatoes.

Agree with Dale and Alice. Thirty minutes was way too long for my pressure cooker. Tried 15 minutes and will go down to 12 for next round. However, I must say, that even at 15 minutes, these were the best mashed potatoes I ever had. I used a can of chicken broth in the bottom of the cooker. Delish and so easy to mash with a fork! Will keep trying until I get time exactly right.
